Title: N/A

reviewText: This wonderful series finishes up by resolving the Lord of Terror arc. When we left off, Urd was possessed by the mysterious entity. Belldandy had removed her power limiter to attempt to save her sister and the world. but h can freely move between and possess other bodies at will, making him impossible to pin down. The Almighty sends down the Valkyrie Lind to kill the Lord of Terror, but as long as he possesses someone that Belldandy cares about, she won't let Lind finish off the Lord of Terror. The way he was finally brought down... well I certainly didn't see it coming.The final two episodes were specials in Japan, I think. The first involves Urd reverting to her child state and Skuld being advanced to an adult age.  Both of these episodes were nicely done and touching, and seeing chibi-Belldandy AND Aoshima getting more Urd-style punishment makes it even sweeter. Problem is, now all of us AMG fans have to wait until Season 2 is released.The entire series has been wonderful, with great storylines and beautiful animation and characters, and the final volume is no different. Highly recommended.
summary: An excellent end to the first season

reviewText: The story has been pretty much sumarized by some of the other reviewers, so I wont recap too much. But the battle is a wonderful demonstration of the relationship that has developed between Belldandy and Keichi, though even at the end these two still haven't kissed (well, on the lips at least). The other two episodes at the end are chances for the other two goddesses to shine; as Urd becomes a kid, while Skuld gets a day as a grownup, with all the emotional complications one might expect, along with a few surprises.I have always felt that this was an exceptional series, and this collection hasn't changed that verdict. I'm glad that it sounds like the story will continue (though it raises questions about this collections title). I don't know about most, but I'm going to stick with this one
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was pretty down on Volume 5 of this series and thought I might lose interest in the franchise forever. Thankfully, Volume 6 is a return to form that got me right back into the show. Instead of focusing on all the angst of Urd and annoying habits of Skuld, comedy, and FUNNY comedy has entered the picture again, even as The Lord of Terror still has possession of Urd's body. The Almighty (who I assume is God) is debating on whether or not to send one of his warrior valkyries down to take out the Lord of Terror, and Urd along with him. But Belldandy makes one last effort and breaks the seal on her full power against the wishes of God to save her sister and Keiichi. The last two episodes of the series are the best and both involve shapeshifting brought on by a power loss in Heaven that drains the Goddesses powers. In the first, Urd shrinks to the size of a elementary school girl, along with a unquenchable thirst for sake! She meets and befriends a young boy in the park as she finds herself enjoying being a kid again. In the last episode, the opposite happens as Skuld changes into a young WOMAN and finally gets her wish to be a grownup. The problem is she finds it's harder than it looks to be and adult, and she also feels some stirrings in her heart towards Keiichi!The problem in the previous volume was that it wasn't funny. But in Volume 6, even in the apocalyptic battle with the Lord of Terror you sense that nobody is going to get hurt and there are even bits of comedy during the fight to save the Earth. When Ah My Goddess tries to take itself too seriously it falls into the hands of boredom. I was really surprised to see this show make a resurgence. My favorites of the disk were the last two episodes for sure, because we got to see into the spirits of Urd and Skuld. It was nice to see Urd having a tender relationship with that boy because growing up nobody really cared for her except Belldandy, because of her half-demon lineage. Even Skuld, who I usually hate as a character, found a place in my affections with episode 26 as she realizes there are some advantages to being a kid, and that maybe her hostility towards Keiichi is really an outlet for something deeper. All in all, a really good volume. As far as I know, the makers of the anime plan to continue this series and adapt all the manga volumes as long as there is an audience for it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I don't understand why did they name this DVD as the Last Dance. Last Dance sounds much like Belldandy and keiichi get separated after something sad. Actually, that is what I was worrying before watching the DVD. Goddess fans, such a horrible thing does never happen here! As Belldandy always says, "Yokata."The volume 6 Last Dance is the last release of Goddess series, at least until now in summer 2006 in the U.S. I don't know whether they are making another film like vol. 7 or 8, but my impression after watching it is that it is still very wide open for more stories after this volume. It contains 4 episodes. First two episodes are the continuum of the Lord of Terror story of vol. 5. In vol. 5, Urd was possessed by demon that turned her into the Lord of Terror who were prophesized to destroy human civilization. The first two episodes of this volume are the battle against the Lord of Terror.To wake Urd up from the demon and also rescue Keiichi kidnapped by Mara, Belldandy unseals her power limiter off and reveals her full force as a first class goddess. Personally, I was expecting Belldandy to be real mighty but she indeed seems not too much stronger than before. Anyway, Urd and Mara succeeded in initiating Ultimate Destruction program, which, as you can imagine, will destroy everything in the world.There are two resolution sent from the heaven: Lynd, a warrior goddess whose duty is to eliminate the Lord of Terror by all means and a magic flute that can seal the Destruction program. Belldandy manages to seal the Destruction Program by playing the flute, but new problems occur. First, the Destruction Program sucked all the demonic powers of the Lord of Terror, and itself claims as the new Lord of Terror instead of Urd. Thanks to it, Urd gets free from the demon, but the Destruction program now has a power to reproduce itself. It now jumps from one thing or person to another and finally possesses Keiichi's body. Of course, Belldandy cannot attack keiichi and even has to protect him from Lynd who wants to end up the situation by sacrificing "one man." Finally, Belldandy gives her own body to the Lord of Terror and asks to free keiichi from captivity.Ok, I think I said too much already. I don't want ruin your enjoyment with this DVD. One thing that I want to add on the first two episodes is that Belldandy makes a very very important decision here.Next two episodes are somewhat like bonus attachments of original storyline. During the previous phenomenal battle, the igdrasil system was damaged and, as a side effect, goddess sisters were affected more or less. In original Nordic myth, Urd governs past, Belldandy the present, and Skuld the future. Because of the temporary system error of the igdrasil, Urd's time gets stopped at past and she turned into a kid. Plus, during the time she needs alternative energy to sustain her goddess power. The energy source is... What do you think? Yes, alcoholic beverages. In this episode, drinking child urd is playing with a boy and gets close to him. The boy falls in love with this little drinking girl and this is for their story. By the way, Belldandy became small to save igdrasil energy. If you watched The Adventures of Mini Goddess series, then you may enjoy these last two episodes.In the last episode, the time of Skuld sets to the future due to the igdrasil system error. The result is that Skuld becomes a beautiful lady as she always dreamed. Because new version of igdrasil will be full restored in a day, lady Skuld wants to fully enjoy her only adult day. Skuld borrows (I think this is correct description: ) Keiichi from mini Belldandy and they are going out to the downtown. When being together and mistakenly seen as a couple, Skuld finds herself to feel strange but strong emotion to keiichi. Confused and little scared, Skuld struggles but also enjoys this embarrassing feeling.All in all, the 4 episodes of this DVD are somewhat lacking focus, compared with other volumes. The plot of first two battle episodes are little scattered and a bit unorganized. The little urd episode is ok but I guess it is a bit off the track. The lady Skuld episode is also all right but personally Belldandy is already too much for him, so Skuld on top of it...... is well.... Sounds too much luck just to him. But, still there are many sweet treats and laugh generating factors in this volume. Oh, there is a special feature with many images also. Hope they have a plan to make volume 7 soon.
summary: Why call it last Dance? I never know.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Last Dance" has four episodes. The first two wrap up the crisis introduced mid-way through the last episode of Volume 5. There are several "false dawns" here- places where the villain is erroneously thought to be defeated- but our heroes have two things going for them: Belldandy's steadfast love, and Sculd's cleverness (even though the technology employed at the end is a bit dated now.)  Also interesting is the continued borrowing of elements from Norse mythology.The final two episodes give each of Belldandy's sisters a chance for romances of their own. Urd's is interesting (Urd has always been my favorite character in the series), but Sculd's is the real gem - she is suddenly propelled into the body of a young woman, with the emotions that go along with it, and her first crush is on the young human male she knows best- Keiichi! It was wonderful to see Sculd's view of Keiichi turned 180 degrees, and even if the audience suspects all along that it won't last even a whole episode, maybe this helped set the stage for the warmer, more tolerant view of Keiichi that Sculd holds in the Ah! My Goddess! movie.
Title: N/A
